title.value: Aperiodic brain activity and response to anesthesia vary in disorders of consciousness
title.justification: The title of the paper is clearly stated on the first page of the document.
title.quote: Aperiodic brain activity and response to anesthesia vary in disorders of consciousness

extractions.description: This study investigates the aperiodic EEG component of individuals in a disorder of consciousness (DOC) and how it changes in response to anesthesia, as well as its relationship with the brain's information richness and criticality.

type.justification: The paper conducts experiments on individuals by analyzing EEG data to study the aperiodic component's response to anesthesia, indicating empirical research.
type.quote: Our results demonstrate that the EEG aperiodic com- ponent is more informative about the participantsâ€™ level of consciousness than the oscillatory component.

name.justification: The study focuses on brain activity and consciousness, which are primary concerns of neuroscience.
name.quote: The aperiodic EEG component has been historically neglected; this research highlights the necessity of considering this measure for the assessment of individuals in DOC and future research that seeks to understand the neurophysiological underpinnings of consciousness.

name.justification: The paper discusses findings related to brain electrophysiology extensively, emphasizing EEG data analysis.
name.quote: Recent advances in electrophysiology ( Donoghue et al., 2020 , 2021 ) suggest that analyzing EEG data solely from the perspective of oscillatory patterns may lead to erroneous or incomplete representations of the underlying neurophysiological processes.

name.justification: The dataset mentioned involves EEG recordings from individuals in a disorder of consciousness (DOC) and is analyzed for aperiodic components.
name.quote: High-density EEG was recorded from 43 individuals in a DOC, with 16 of these individuals undergoing a protocol of propofol anesthesia.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The dataset was reported and utilized within the scope of this study to analyze aperiodic EEG components.
referenced_paper_title.quote: High-density EEG was recorded from 43 individuals in a DOC, with 16 of these individuals undergoing a protocol of propofol anesthesia.
